name: methyl_propyl_sulfide
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: 1,3-propanedisulfide has a melting point of -109.4 degrees Celsius. The basic unit for this compound can be considered propane, which has a melting point of -18.0 degrees Celsius. The sulfur atom introduces a rigid structure and potential hydrogen bonding, which can increase the melting point. The methyl group introduces a bulky side chain, which can reduce the melting point due to steric hindrance. The propyl group introduces a rigid structure and potential hydrogen bonding, which can increase the melting point. The sulfur atom introduces a rigid structure and potential hydrogen bonding, which can increase the melting point. The exact impact of these structural modifications is difficult to quantify without experimental data or detailed computational studies.
